Opened issue "Version 2.8.1 with .NET 4.7.1 creates dozens of unneeded library references" (#401) at OfficeDev/Open-XML-SDK
Events.RelatedBody:
**Description**

If you add version 2.8.1 (via NuGet) to a project that targets .NET 4.7.1, then it will pull down dozens of System.X libraries, some of which will causes reference issues with larger projects. 

**Information**

- .NET Target: 4.7.1
- DocumentFormat.OpenXml Version: 2.8.1

**Repro**
Create a new solution with a console app project targeting 4.7.1. Add version 2.8.1 via NuGet. 

**Observed**

Dozens of extra unneeded libraries are added. 

**Expected**

It should only add 3 additional libraries: 
* Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms
* NETStandard.Library
* System.IO.Packaging

**Workaround**
If you install NETStandard.Library before DocumentFormat.OpenXml, and upgrade Microsoft.NETCore.Platforms, then only additional library installed is System.IO.Packaging.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "DocumentBuilder merges numbering definitions referencing the same abstract numbering definition" (#84) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
When building a document, `DocumentBuilder` merges [numbering definition instances](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/documentformat.openxml.wordprocessing.numberinginstance.aspx) referencing the same [abstract numbering definition](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/documentformat.openxml.wordprocessing.abstractnum.aspx). This leads to bugs if the numbering definitions contain [numbering level definition overrides](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/documentformat.openxml.wordprocessing.leveloverride.aspx).

For an example, see the [example document](https://github.com/OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools/files/434902/Example.of.numbering.definitions.with.same.abstract.numering.definition.docx) and the [processed version](https://github.com/OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools/files/434917/Example.of.numbering.definitions.with.same.abstract.numering.definition-processed.docx). When opened in Word, the example document displays three lists, each numbered from 1 to 3. After being included in a document built with `DocumentBuilder`, however, the processed version displays as three lists with a consecutive numbering from 1 to 9.

Technically, this is due to the `CopyNumbering` method in `WordBuilder` only creating a new numbering definition if it can't find one using the same abstract numbering definition. Instead, it should use a map like `CopyComments`.

This issue is the cause of a bug in our system, so I'll will start working on a fix.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "Use a map when copying numbering definition instances in DocumentBuil…" (#114) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
Use a map when copying numbering definition instances in DocumentBuilder instead of identifying instances by the abstract numbering id.

Fixes OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools#84

Supersedes OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools#86

Merged pull request "Remove dependency on MediaDataPartType, which doesn't contain MP4" (#110) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody: MediaDataPartType isn't really needed. It's only used to find the content type and file extension for a media file, and we already have those from the previous media part. Since MediaDataPartType doesn't contain a value for MP4, this Fixes #65.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "DocumentAssembler generates large file" (#202) at OfficeDev/Open-Xml-PowerTools
Events.RelatedBody:
The size of the Assembled Document is around the same size as the template (word doc) from which it was produced. In my current case, this is a problem, because my word doc template is 27 megs, but has numerous conditionals (especially around large images I need to hide/show based on data). 

After the doc is assembled, I expect the assembled file to only be around 5 megs. Testing this assertion, I can open the 27 meg assembled document into MS Word, make a small change (add a space for example), save it, and now the saved file is only around 5 megs. This can make a huge difference in user experience, for example, when my users attempt to use my generated document as attachments in mail systems with attachment size limits.
